position.marginalia_text: Qui sit si venti pluuiaq[ue] similiter descendu[n]t, quod pluuia[e] non ferantur lateraliter sup[er] Terram, veluti feru[n]tur venti, sed quod semp[er] ad [rectum] terra[e] cadunt. Qui sit [etia[m]] quod no[n] [secundum] stellar[um] motu[m] vna [etu[m]] localite progrediu[n]t[ur] pluvia[e]!

marginalia.translation: What may be if the winds and rain fall down similarly, because the rain is brought laterally onto the earth, like the winds are carried, but because they always fall towards the right of the earth. What may also be because the rain proceeds not following the movement of the stars, gone in one locality.

marginalia.anchor_text: Buxenpuluer das da kompt auß den Cauernis vnd Emunctorijs der Cataracten, der Vulcanischen Windtsterne

position.marginalia_text: Si ita ex stellaru[m] corporibus cu[m] Venti tum pluvia[e] descendant ad nos: quid [dicemus] de stellis interpositis inter ip[s]as ventosas vel pluuiosas et nos. [habet] quod a ventis [...st..ijs] pulsentur, an non. Vel quid [dice...].

marginalia.translation: If thus both the winds and the rain fall down from the bodies of the stars towards us: what do we say about the stars placed between those winds, rains, and us. It has that they were beaten by the winds, whether not. Or what [...]?

underline.text: Buxenpuluer das da kompt auß den Cauernis vnd Emunctorijs der Cataracten, der Vulcanischen Windtsterne
